title-group.article-title: A new dwarf schendylid centipede (Chilopoda: Geophilomorpha: Schendylidae) with a low number of legs from Serbia, Balkan Peninsula

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: A new dwarf schendylid centipede ( Chilopoda : Geophilomorpha : Schendylidae ) with a low number of legs from Serbia , Balkan Peninsula
DALIBOR Z. STOJANOVIĆ 1,* , MIRKO ŠEVIĆ 1,2 & SLOBODAN E. MAKAROV 1,3

1
University of Belgrade —Faculty of Biology, Institute of Zoology, Studentski Trg 16, 11000 Belgrade , Serbia

2
�
mirko.sevic@bio.bg.ac.rs ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-1979-9516

3
�
slobodan@bio.bg.ac.rs ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-4365-8182
*Corresponding author: � dstojanovic@bio.bg.ac.rs; https://orcid.org/0000-0003-1602-1247

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Schendyla antici
sp. nov.
, a dwarf geophilomorph from the Mt. Medvednik (Western Serbia , Balkan Peninsula), is described and illustrated based on the specimens extracted from the soil samples. A detailed comparison with all species within the genus is provided. The new species has the lowest number of leg-bearing segments within the genus
Schendyla Bergsøe & Meinert, 1866
, and one of the lowest in the order Geophilomorpha in general.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words :
Schendyla
,
new species
, Medvednik , Balkans , taxonomy

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
A new dwarf
Schendyla species
is described here, collected from a single locality in the western part of Serbia (Balkan Peninsula). Both sexes are described in detail and illustrated by drawings and photographs.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: The new species was found by Dr. Dragan Antić through soil extraction from an improvised Berlese-Tullgren funnel in August 2011 . The soil sample was taken from an old beech forest on Mt. Medvednik (Western Serbia ). Thereby, only one specimen of the new species was collected then. In June 2021 , after a failed attempt to find more living specimens at the same locality, the soil samples were brought to the laboratory of the Institute of Zoology, University of Belgrade —Faculty of Biology. After removing the thin covering of leaf litter, the soil was taken from upper layers, approximately at a depth of 15–20 cm and from the surface of approximately one square meter. After extraction in the Berlese-Tullgren funnel, additional 17 specimens were collected ( five males , nine females , and three juveniles ). The seven additional specimens ( two males and five females ) were collected in November 2023 , so that the photographs of live animals could be taken, and finally they were added to the non-type material.

Due to the small size of the specimens, most of the taxonomically important morphological structures are only weakly visible. For the description, one male and two females were immersed in 10% KOH (for 1–2 days). This removed all the soft tissue, and the external morphological characters become more visible on the remaining chitinous exoskeleton. Specimens treated in this way (their dissected parts or whole) were mounted in glycerol as temporary microscope preparations and observed with a Carl Zeiss Axioscope 40 microscope. Species identification was performed by using a Nikon DS-Fi2 camera with a Nikon DS-L3 camera controller attached to a Nikon SMZ 1270 binocular stereomicroscope. The specimens were measured using a dissecting stereomicroscope Carl Zeiss Stemi 2000-C with an AxioCam MRc camera and integrated Axio Vs40 software packages. Images of the selected morphological characters were photographed using a Canon PowerShot A80 digital camera connected to an Axioscope 40 microscope, some of which were used for making drawings by crossing the lines from pictures on a computer monitor. Images of the species habitus ( Fig. 1C ) and of the anterior sternites ( Fig. 3F ) were taken using a Zeiss Discovery V12, with a Leica Flexcam C3 digital camera mounted. All photographs were stacked with a Zerene Stacker. The geographical location of the type locality ( Fig. 1A ) was plotted using Adobe Photoshop CS6 software and a blank simple map of Serbia (downloaded from “d-maps.com”). The photos of the type locality and of living animals were taken with the Olympus Stylus Tough TG-6 digital camera ( Figs 1B , 2 ). All plates were processed with Adobe Photoshop CS6.

The terminology used in this study follows
. The characterization of the antennal sensilla follows Müller et al. (2009). Finally, to confirm the morphological uniqueness of the new species, it is compared with all other species within the genus
Schendyla
listed by
. This implies a comparison with the accessible literature data, considering both the original descriptions and the additionally reported morphological variabilities of the species (see Table 1 ).

Each specimen is labelled and stored separately in a plastic tube filled with 70% ethanol and deposited in the collections of the Institute of Zoology, University of Belgrade—Faculty of Biology (IZB), the Natural History Museum Vienna , Austria ( NHMW ), the National Museum of Natural History, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences in Sofia , Bulgaria (NMNHS) and the Senckenberg Museum of Natural History Görlitz, Germany (VNR).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Taxonomy

mixed-citation.named-content: A new dwarf schendylid centipede (Chilopoda: Geophilomorpha: Schendylidae) with a low number of legs from Serbia, Balkan Peninsula

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Material studied .
Holotype
: male (IZB ChG0151), SERBIA , Mt. Medvednik , Kulina hill, near mountain hut “Krušik” (coordinates 44.20620 , 19.65880 ; elevation about
830 m a.s.l.
;
), old beech forest, extracted from the soil,
2 August 2011
, D. Antić leg.

Paratypes
: five males (IZB ChG0152, IZB ChG0153, NHMW MY10371 , NMNHS-Myriapoda-10830, and VNR 021239-1b)
,
nine females (IZB ChG0154–IZB ChG0159, NHMW MY10372 , NMNHS-Myriapoda-10831, and VNR 021239-1a), same locality as in the holotype ,
8 June 2021
, old beech forest, extracted from the soil, D. Stojanović , M. Šević & D. Antić leg.

Additional
non-type material
: three juvenile females (IZB ChG0160), all on adolescens 3 stage, same data as in
paratypes ; two males (IZB ChG0162 A, B) and
five females (IZB ChG0163 A–E), same locality, extracted from the soil,
14 November 2023
, D. Stojanović & M. Šević leg.

Name.
The new species is named in honour of our close friend and colleague, the well-known Serbian myriapodologist Dr. Dragan Antić ( Belgrade , Serbia ), who collected the first specimen of the new species ( holotype ) and participated in the collection of most of the remaining specimens. The epithet, a name in the genitive case, is a patronym
.

Diagnosis. The unique combination of characters clearly distinguishes the new species from its congeners: 29–31 leg-bearing segments; small body size (less than 8 mm ); labrum with 10 median and three moderately longer and pointed lateral denticles on each side; minute denticles on forcipular trochanteroprefemora (small and weakly noticeable), without denticles on femora and tibiae, and with small basal denticle on tarsungulum; mandibular dentate lamella undivided, with 6–8 teeth (usually eight); pretarsus of second maxillae slightly flattened distally, without filaments; absence of ventral pore-fields in all sternites; last terminal article of ultimate legs as small tubercle, armed with minute rudimentary apical claw and with few accessory spines close to the basis of the claw.

Description. Number of leg pairs and body size : Holotype male with 29 pairs of legs, body length 7.2 mm . All paratype males with 29 pairs of legs, body length 4.8–6.6 mm (average 5.6 mm ); all paratype females with 31 pairs of legs, body length 4.5–8.0 mm (average 6.3 mm ). Non-type juvenile females also with 31 pairs of legs, and body length around 4 mm . Additional non-type material follows the similar pattern, both males with 29 leg-bearing segments and a body length of 5.5–7.0 mm (average 6.3 mm ); all females with 31 leg-bearing segments, with a body length of 6.4–7.7 (average 7.0 mm).

Cephalic capsule : Oval, ca . 1.3–1.5 (usually 1.4) times longer than wide, with evenly distributed setae on surface (
).

Mandible : Pectinate lamella with ca . 12–14 hyaline teeth, dentate lamellae undivided, with 6–8 teeth (usually eight) in one block (
).

First maxillae : Coxosternite undivided, without coxosternal lappets and setae (
). Basal telopodital article ca . 2 times wider than long, with moderately long and thin lappets (approximately three times longer than wide; apically rounded), without setae. Distal article ca . 2.5 times longer than wide, distally rounded, with one ventral seta each. Coxal projection subtriangular, distally rounded, with 1+1 ventral setae on about half of the projection length.

Walking legs : Chaetotaxy similar throughout the entire body length. Distribution and relative size of setae as in
. Apical claws almost straight, distally pointed out and moderately curved, without accessory spines in the base.

Intraspecific variation : Based on all specimens analyzed in this study ( type and non-type), the new species shows no intrasexual variability in the number of leg-bearing segments, fixed to 29 in males and 31 in females. All collected specimens are of a small size ( ca . 5–8 mm ), with a relatively similar coloration and setation, and with similar size and proportion of body parts (antennae, cephalic plate, forcipules, ultimate legs, etc.). When comparing the sexes, in addition to the differences in the number of leg-bearing segments and genital structures, it was observed that females are slightly larger than males (average size 6.5 mm vs 5.8 mm ). Also, the males have a more pronounced setation on the posterior half of the ultimate sternite and the coxopleura. There are no distinct differences between the sexes in the other morphological characteristics.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Until now, only a few species with less than 31 body segments are known within Geophilomorpha , while the lowest number of leg-bearing segments is 27. Such a habitus characterizes two species of
Schendylops Cook, 1899
from Amazonia ( Brazil ), viz .,
S. oligopus ( Pereira, Minelli & Barbieri, 1995 )
, with 29 and 31 leg-bearing segments in males and females, respectively, and only with one male with 27 leg-bearing segments from the rather large sample (
), and
S. ramirezi Pereira, 2013
, commonly with 27 and 29 in males and females, respectively (
). Furthermore, one schendylid and two geophilid species are known with at least some specimens with 29 leg-bearing segments, respectively
Dinogeophilus oligopodus Pereira, 1984
from Argentina (in both sexes),
Geophilus richardi Brölemann, 1904
recorded from France and Italy (commonly with 31 and 33 in males and females, respectively; but see also
), and the troglobiomorphic species
G. persephones Foddai & Minelli, 1999
known from a cave in southern France (described from a single male with 29 pairs of legs). The
Schendyla antici
sp. nov.
, described here, with 29 pair of legs in the males, is the species with the lowest number of leg-bearing segments within the genus and at the same time, one of the species with the lowest number within the order Geophilomorpha .
......Continued on the next page
......Continued on the next page
......Continued on the next page

Besides the common diagnostic features of the genus
Schendyla
(specific for all members of the genus; viz., two large coxal pores on the coxopleuron near the margin of the sternite of the ultimate leg-bearing segment, or the absence of the coxosternal denticles and chitin-line),
Schendyla antici
sp. nov.
shares at least some of the additional morphological features (specific only to certain species or groups of species within the genus; viz. , presence of denticles on forcipular trochanteroprefemora and apical claw on ultimate legs, absence of ventral pore-fields) with all species of this genus (see Table 1 ). For example, denticles on the forcipular trochanteroprefemora were found in only six species, namely:
S. armata Brölemann, 1901
,
S. dentata ( Brölemann & Ribaut, 1911 )
,
S. monoeci Brölemann, 1904
,
S. negreai ( Dărăbanţu & Matic, 1969 )
,
S. tyrolensis ( Meinert, 1870 )
and
S. verneri ( Folkmanová & Dobroruka, 1960 )
; but only two of them (
S. monoeci
and
S. verneri
) have small denticles like those found in the new species (see Table 1 ). Additionally, about 10
Schendyla species
share the complete absence of sternal pore-fields with the new species described here ( Table 1 ). However, the low number of leg-bearing segments (29 or 31) recorded in
Schendyla antici
sp. nov.
is the simplest way to separate it from congeners. Only three species have an approximate number of leg-bearing segments,
viz., S. armat
a (the lowest reported number is 33 in females and 35 in males),
S. verneri
(31 reported by
, but without specifying whether in males or females) and
S. walachica Verhoeff, 1900
( 33–35 in both sexes). In all other species, the lowest recorded number of leg-bearing segments is 35 or more ( Table 1 ).

Based on the combination of only three previously mentioned characters (small size, number of leg-bearing segments and presence of a small denticles on the forcipular trochanteroprefemora), it is evident that the species
S. verneri
has the greatest overlap of morphological characters with our new species.
Schendyla verneri
is a small species known only from the type series (at least four specimens ) known from four localities in Russia and Ukraine , and it differs from
Schendyla antici
sp. nov.
in some diagnostic characters, such as: a smaller number of teeth on the mandibular dentate lamella (only three vs. eight in
S. antici
sp. nov.
), the presence of a few scattered pores on the anterior sternites (vs. complete absence in
S. antici
sp. nov.
) and the complete absence of terminal claws on ultimate legs (vs. presence of the rudimentary claw in
S. antici
sp. nov.
).

A morphologically very similar species is also the southeastern European
S. walachica
, with the addition that it has been recorded in the few neighboring countries ( Bulgaria , Greece , Moldova and Romania ). Major differences are the twice as long body of
S. walachica
compared to
S. antici
sp. nov .
, the absence of denticles on the forcipular trochanteroprefemora and the presence of sternal pore-fields from the second to the ninth (or the eleventh) sternites.

Finally,
Schendyla antici
sp. nov .
shows many more differences than similarities with two other species mentioned above (
S. armata
and
S. monoeci
) (see Table 1 ). The above arguments clearly justify the description of our specimens as a new species.
Schendyla antici
sp. nov.
is the third species of the genus
Schendyla
in Serbia , in addition to two others previously reported species, viz .,
S. carniolensis ( Verhoeff, 1902 )
and
S. monoeci
(
;
;
). The type locality (beech forest on Kulina hill on the Medvednik Mt.) is the only known locality of
S. antici
sp . nov .
, where the new species can currently be considered endemic.
